stem: The nurse is performing an initial assessment on a newborn (2 hours old). Match each finding with whether it is a Normal/Expected Finding or an Abnormal/Concern-ing Finding.

rows.text: Heart rate of 140 bpm while sleeping.
Blueish coloration of the hands and feet (Acrocyanosis).
Nasal flaring and chest wall retractions during quiet breathing.
Absence of meconium passage within the first 24 hours.
A soft 'indentation' in the center of the head (anterior fontanelle).

rationale.correct: Newborn assessment requires distinguishing transition from pathology. (r1) Normal newborn HR is 110-160. (r2) Acrocyanosis is normal for the first 24-48 hours. (r3) Nasal flaring/retractions are classic signs of respiratory distress. (r4) Failure to pass meconium suggests Hirschsprung disease or Cystic Fibrosis (meconium ileus). (r5) The anterior fontanelle should be soft and flat.
rationale.incorrect: A sunken fontanelle (not shown) indicates dehydration; a bulging one indicates increased ICP.
clinicalPearls: Assess the newborn's apical pulse for a full minute for accuracy.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: BLUE hands/feet (Acrocyanosis) = GOOD (Normal). BLUE lips/torso (Central cyanosis) = BAD (Emergency).

reviewUnits.heading: Initial Newborn Care
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for thermoregulation, feeding success, and cardiorespiratory stability. Identifying cues of distress allows for rapid transition to NICU care if needed.
